steps.instruction: Fill the pot halfway with water.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Fill the pot fully with water.
steps.explanation: Filling the pot halfway avoids overfilling and allows for boiling.
steps.wrong_explanation: Filling the pot fully saves water and energy.
steps.safety_reminder: Be careful not to overfill the pot to prevent spills.
steps.clarification: When I say fill the pot halfway, I mean the water should reach about 2 inches below the rim to prevent any spills while boiling.

steps.instruction: Add a small amount of salt to the water.
steps.explanation: Adding salt improves flavor and helps the pasta cook evenly.
steps.wrong_explanation: Salt is unnecessary as it adds extra sodium.
steps.safety_reminder: Use caution when adding salt to avoid splashes.
steps.clarification: By a small amount, I mean about one teaspoon. This will help enhance the flavor and ensure the pasta cooks properly.

steps.instruction: Place the pot on the stove and turn it to medium-high heat until the water boils.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Place the pot on the stove and turn it to low heat.
steps.explanation: Medium-high heat brings the water to a boil faster.
steps.wrong_explanation: Low heat will eventually boil the water but is more energy-efficient.
steps.safety_reminder: Stay attentive to avoid boiling over.
steps.clarification: Medium-high heat is usually around 7 or 8 on a dial that goes up to 10. This will bring the water to a boil more quickly.

steps.instruction: Add the pasta carefully to the boiling water.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Add the pasta before the water boils.
steps.explanation: Adding pasta to boiling water ensures even cooking.
steps.wrong_explanation: Adding pasta to cold water is fine and saves time.
steps.safety_reminder: Be careful not to splash boiling water.
steps.clarification: Wait until you see large, consistent bubbles in the water before adding the pasta to ensure it cooks evenly.

steps.instruction: Set a timer for 10 minutes to cook the pasta to an al dente texture.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Set a timer for 5 minutes to cook the pasta.
steps.explanation: Cooking for 10 minutes achieves an al dente texture.
steps.wrong_explanation: Cooking for 5 minutes will be sufficient for al dente texture.
steps.safety_reminder: Do not leave the stove unattended while cooking.
steps.clarification: Al dente means the pasta should be firm to the bite. Setting a timer for 10 minutes will help you achieve this perfect texture.

steps.instruction: In a separate pan, add a small amount of olive oil to heat and set it to low-medium heat.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Add a large amount of olive oil and heat on high.
steps.explanation: Low-medium heat prevents burning the oil and ingredients.
steps.wrong_explanation: High heat speeds up the cooking process.
steps.clarification: Low-medium heat is around 4 or 5 on a dial that goes up to 10. This helps to gently heat the oil without burning it.

steps.instruction: Add the chopped onion to the olive oil.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Add whole onion pieces to the olive oil.
steps.explanation: Chopped onion cooks evenly and adds flavor.
steps.safety_reminder: Use a spatula to stir the onions.
steps.clarification: Chopped means cutting the onion into small, uniform pieces. This allows them to cook evenly and release their flavors effectively.

steps.instruction: Stir the onion gently until it becomes fragrant, but avoid browning it too much.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Cook the onion until it is dark brown.
steps.explanation: Cooking until fragrant enhances the flavor without burning.
steps.wrong_explanation: Browning deeply enhances the flavor further.
steps.clarification: Fragrant means you can smell the aroma of the onions. Stir them gently to avoid burning and ensure they become soft and aromatic.

steps.instruction: Add canned diced tomatoes to the pan and stir well with the onion.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Add whole canned tomatoes to the pan.
steps.explanation: Diced tomatoes mix well and cook evenly with the onion.
steps.wrong_explanation: Whole tomatoes add a rustic texture.
steps.clarification: Diced means the tomatoes are cut into small, uniform pieces. This helps them mix well and cook evenly with the onions.

steps.instruction: Season with salt and pepper to taste.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Skip seasoning or add excessive salt.
steps.wrong_explanation: Seasoning is optional and doesn't affect the taste much.
steps.safety_reminder: Use moderate amounts to avoid over-seasoning.
steps.clarification: To taste means adding enough until you find the flavor satisfying. Start with a pinch of each and adjust as needed.

steps.instruction: Let the sauce simmer on low heat to blend the flavors.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Cook the sauce on high heat for a short time.
steps.clarification: Simmering means small bubbles should form gently on the surface, allowing the flavors to meld together.

steps.instruction: Carefully drain the pasta when the cooking is done.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Drain the pasta immediately without checking doneness.
steps.explanation: Properly drained pasta has a better texture.
steps.clarification: Use a colander to drain the pasta over the sink, shaking gently to remove excess water while ensuring itâ€™s cooked to your desired texture.

steps.instruction: Combine the pasta with the sauce in the pan and mix it well.
steps.explanation: Combining pasta and sauce ensures even coating.
steps.wrong_explanation: Separate serving allows for personal mixing.
steps.safety_reminder: Be cautious with the hot pan.
steps.clarification: Stir until the pasta is fully coated with the sauce, making sure each piece is well covered for the best taste.

steps.instruction: Serve the pasta on a plate and enjoy.
steps.incorrect_instruction: Leave the pasta in the pan for serving.
steps.explanation: Plating enhances presentation and ease of eating.
steps.wrong_explanation: Serving from the pan saves dishes.
steps.clarification: Use a large spoon or tongs to serve the pasta onto plates, and enjoy the meal with a great presentation.
